modules.title: Resilience vs Availability: what you’re really buying

pages.title: Resilience: keep operating when reality punches the building

content_blocks.text: Resilience is your system’s ability to **keep functioning** or **recover quickly** when bad things happen (failures, disasters, attacks, mistakes).
Availability is the outcome users feel: “Is it up and usable right now?” Resilience is how you *protect* availability over time.
A practical mental model: **prevent** what you can, **absorb** what you can’t, and **recover** fast.

checks.prompt: Which phrase best matches 'resilience' in security architecture?
options: Ability to recover and continue operations after disruption
Using only a single vendor for simplicity
checks.explanation: Resilience is about withstanding disruption and recovering/continuing operations.

pages.title: Design trade-offs: cost, responsiveness, and reality

content_blocks.text: Resilience design always involves trade-offs: **cost**, **complexity**, **ease of recovery**, and **responsiveness**.
A classic failure mode is a **single point of failure (SPoF)**: one component dies and the whole service faceplants.
Security+ expects you to connect resilience decisions to business needs: what must stay up, what can be down, and for how long.

checks.prompt: A 'single point of failure' is best described as:
options: A control that is too expensive to maintain
One component whose failure can stop the entire service
A server that has too many users
checks.explanation: A single point of failure is any element whose failure disrupts or stops the system.

modules.title: Architecture choices: multi-cloud and platform diversity

pages.title: Multi-cloud: resilience through not putting all eggs in one basket

content_blocks.text: **Multi-cloud** spreads critical workloads across multiple cloud providers (or provider regions) so one provider outage doesn’t take you down.
Upside: reduces vendor-specific outages and some provider risk. Downside: higher complexity (skills, tooling, integration).
Good exam instinct: multi-cloud is often a **resilience** strategy, not a security magic spell.

checks.prompt: Multi-cloud is primarily used to improve:
checks.explanation: Multi-cloud is mainly a resilience/availability tactic to reduce dependency on one provider.

pages.title: Platform diversity: harder to break everything at once (but harder to manage)

content_blocks.text: **Platform diversity** means using different vendors/solutions so a single exploit or failure doesn’t wipe out the entire environment.
It can reduce systemic risk (one vuln ≠ total outage), but increases operational complexity and human error risk.
Exam takeaway: diversity helps against **common-mode failures**, but you pay for it in training and integration.

checks.prompt: A common downside of platform diversity is:
checks.explanation: Diversity typically increases complexity, which can raise cost and the chance of human error.

modules.title: High availability: load balancing vs clustering (don’t mix these up)

pages.title: Load balancing: split client load across multiple systems

content_blocks.text: **Load balancing** distributes client requests across multiple servers using rules/health checks.
Why it matters: handles changing load, supports rolling upgrades, and reduces user impact if one node fails.
Exam clue: load balancing is often about **scaling** and **traffic distribution**.

checks.prompt: Load balancing primarily provides:
options: Traffic distribution across servers based on rules/health
A permanent backup of all files
checks.explanation: A load balancer routes requests across multiple servers based on rules and health checks.

pages.title: Clustering: members know each other and work as a unit

content_blocks.text: **Clustering** ties systems together so they act like one service (shared state or coordinated failover).
Clusters can provide redundancy and failover, and in some designs also increase capacity.
Exam clue: clustering is about **coordination** between nodes; load balancing is about **distributing requests**.

checks.prompt: In a cluster, 'all members are aware of all other members' best describes:
checks.explanation: Clusters coordinate membership/state; nodes are aware of each other for failover/coordination.

modules.title: Continuity of operations + scaling + capacity planning

pages.title: Continuity of Operations: keep the business functioning

content_blocks.text: **Continuity of operations** focuses on keeping critical business functions running during disruptions.
It includes both technical systems and the humans/processes needed to run them.
Practical: a perfect DR site is useless if you don’t have staff access, credentials, or a restoration plan.

checks.prompt: Continuity of operations planning must include:
options: People and processes, not just technology
checks.explanation: Continuity planning includes people/processes plus technology.

pages.title: Capacity planning: people + technology + infrastructure

content_blocks.text: Capacity planning for resilience asks: Do we have enough **people**, **technology**, and **infrastructure** when things go wrong?
People: staffing, contracts, third parties. Technology: system capacity and scaling. Infrastructure: networks, storage, power.
Exam trigger: “capacity planning” almost always maps to **people / technology / infrastructure**.

checks.prompt: In this chapter, capacity planning is primarily broken into:
checks.explanation: The chapter frames capacity planning as people, technology, and infrastructure.

modules.title: Testing resilience: tabletop vs simulation vs parallel vs failover

pages.title: Tabletop & simulation: test brains before you test production

content_blocks.text: **Tabletop** exercises are discussion-based walkthroughs of a scenario. Least disruptive.
**Simulation** exercises are more realistic: you simulate conditions and actions (still controlled).
Exam instinct: when asked “least disruptive,” think **tabletop**.

checks.prompt: Which testing exercise is typically the least disruptive?
checks.explanation: Tabletop exercises are discussion-based and least disruptive.

pages.title: Parallel processing & failover: test the hard stuff

content_blocks.text: **Parallel processing** runs workloads on an alternate/hot site in parallel to validate capability (risk of interference if not isolated).
**Failover** exercises switch to the alternate site/system. Most disruptive but most realistic validation.
Exam instinct: when you need to *prove the whole thing works*, failover is the most complete test.

checks.prompt: Which exercise best validates full real-world failover capability?
checks.explanation: Failover exercises provide the most complete real-world validation.

modules.title: Backup fundamentals: full vs incremental vs differential

pages.title: Full / incremental / differential

content_blocks.text: **Full backup** copies everything (biggest time/storage).
**Incremental** copies changes since the last backup (fast to back up, slower to restore because you need the full + all incrementals).
**Differential** copies changes since the last full backup (slower to back up over time, faster to restore than incremental).

checks.prompt: A backup that captures changes since the last full backup is:
checks.explanation: Differential backups capture changes since the last full backup.

pages.title: Backup frequency: it’s about how much loss you can tolerate

content_blocks.text: Backup frequency is driven by how much data loss is acceptable between backups (and the speed you can restore).
Some systems need near-continuous protection (e.g., databases), others can be daily/weekly.
Exam mindset: frequent backups reduce data loss but increase cost and operational overhead.

checks.prompt: Increasing backup frequency primarily reduces:
options: The number of physical controls required
checks.explanation: More frequent backups reduce how much data can be lost between backup points.

pages.title: Snapshots: a point-in-time state (great for VMs)

content_blocks.text: A **snapshot** captures the full state of a system/device at a specific point in time—commonly used with virtual machines.
Use cases: rollback before a patch, clone systems, restore known-good configuration.
Snapshots are not a long-term backup strategy by themselves; they’re a fast rollback tool.

checks.prompt: A snapshot is best described as:
options: A copy of changes since last backup
A point-in-time capture of system state
A method for encrypting backup media
checks.explanation: Snapshots capture system state at a specific time (often for VMs).

pages.title: Images and live boot media: when you can’t trust the OS

content_blocks.text: System **images** can capture a complete system for cloning or nonpersistent deployments (gold master images).
If the OS is compromised or broken, **live boot media** lets you boot a known-good OS to inspect/repair/mount disks safely.
Exam cue: “can’t trust the system” → consider live boot media.

checks.prompt: If a system is compromised and you can’t trust the installed OS, a useful tool is:
checks.explanation: Live boot media boots a trusted OS from removable media to inspect/repair a system.

modules.title: Replication vs journaling: keeping data consistent across sites

pages.title: Replication: synchronous vs asynchronous

content_blocks.text: **Replication** copies live data to another location as changes occur (not periodic like most backups).
**Synchronous replication** writes to both sites before confirming—lower data loss, potentially higher latency.
**Asynchronous replication** confirms locally first, then ships changes—better performance, some potential data loss window.

checks.prompt: Which replication method usually has the lowest data-loss window but may increase latency?
checks.explanation: Synchronous replication confirms writes at both sites before completing the operation.

pages.title: Journaling: point-in-time recovery via change records

content_blocks.text: **Journaling** records changes/transactions so you can replay them to reach a specific point in time.
It’s powerful for databases and transactional systems, but recovery can take longer because the journal must be replayed.
Also: a journal must be protected and backed up—if it’s only on the source system, a single failure can still lose it.

checks.prompt: A key downside of journaling is that recovery can be slower because:
options: The journal must be replayed and applied
checks.explanation: Journaling can slow recovery because you must replay transactions to rebuild state.

modules.title: Backup locations & storage tiers: onsite/offsite, online/nearline/offline

pages.title: Onsite vs offsite: disasters don’t respect your server room

content_blocks.text: **Onsite** backups are fast to restore but can be lost in the same disaster as the primary site.
**Offsite** backups protect against site-level disasters—ideally far enough away to avoid the same regional event.
Exam hint: offsite storage should also be secure in transit and at rest (encryption + custody).

checks.prompt: Why are offsite backups often preferred?
options: They eliminate the need for recovery planning
They protect against site-level disasters affecting primary storage
They remove the need for encryption
checks.explanation: Offsite backups reduce the risk of losing both production and backup to the same disaster.

pages.title: Storage tiers: online vs nearline vs offline

content_blocks.text: **Online** backups are immediately available (fastest restore, higher exposure if attackers reach them).
**Nearline** backups require retrieval steps but are still relatively accessible.
**Offline** (air-gapped/removed media) is slowest but can be strong against ransomware.

checks.prompt: Which tier usually has the slowest retrieval but strongest separation from online attacks?
checks.explanation: Offline storage is slower to retrieve but can reduce exposure to online attacks.

modules.title: Backup security: encryption and key survival

pages.title: Encrypt backups at rest and in transit

content_blocks.text: Backups should be encrypted **at rest** (stored encrypted) and **in transit** (protected during transfer).
The painful truth: if you can’t recover the keys, you can’t recover the backups. Key access during disasters is critical.
Treat backups as high-value data: access control + separation of duties + monitoring.

checks.prompt: A backup that is encrypted at rest is useless if:
options: The encryption keys cannot be recovered
checks.explanation: Without keys, encrypted backups cannot be restored.

pages.title: Third-party/cloud backups: new trust model, new controls

content_blocks.text: Cloud/third-party backups add risks: bandwidth limits, restore time, provider access controls, and shared responsibility.
Common mitigations: separate accounts, stronger IAM, encryption, and clear restoration testing.
Exam cue: “third-party backup” → think of **new security models** and **encryption/identity controls**.

checks.prompt: A common added consideration for third‑party/cloud backups is:
options: They remove all need for access control
checks.explanation: Cloud backups introduce bandwidth/restore-time realities and require strong security controls.

pages.title: UPS: short-term power to survive the gap

content_blocks.text: A **UPS** (uninterruptible power supply) provides immediate short-term power during outages and protects against spikes/sags.
It buys time for safe shutdown or for a generator to start—without it, sudden power loss can corrupt systems.
Exam mindset: UPS = immediate + short duration; generator = longer duration.

checks.prompt: A UPS primarily provides:
options: Immediate short-term power during an outage
checks.explanation: A UPS provides immediate short-term power and power conditioning.

pages.title: Generators: longer-term continuity

content_blocks.text: Generators provide longer-term backup power, but they need fuel, maintenance, and testing.
Resilience planning includes power consumption and compute needs—power is not just a facilities problem.
Exam cue: resilience considerations include **power** and **compute** along with cost and recovery.

checks.prompt: For longer-term backup power during extended outages, the best fit is usually:
checks.explanation: Generators provide longer-term backup power; UPS is short-term bridging/conditioning.

modules.title: Disaster recovery sites: hot vs warm vs cold + geographic dispersion

pages.title: Hot, warm, cold sites (cost vs readiness)

content_blocks.text: **Hot site**: fully ready with systems and data—fastest recovery, highest cost.
**Warm site**: some systems in place, data not current—balanced cost and recovery time.
**Cold site**: space/power/network, but no systems/data—cheapest, slowest to restore.

checks.prompt: Which site type is typically the least expensive but slowest to restore?
checks.explanation: Cold sites have space/power/connectivity but require significant deployment effort.

pages.title: Geographic dispersion: don’t put DR next door

content_blocks.text: Geographic dispersion places backup sites far enough away to avoid the same disaster event (weather, power grid, regional impacts).
Cloud teaches a similar lesson: availability zones/regions can fail, so multi-region design matters even in cloud.
Exam cue: distance often exists to avoid a single event hitting both locations.

checks.prompt: Placing a redundant datacenter 90+ miles away mainly supports:
checks.explanation: Distance is used to reduce the chance that one disaster affects both sites.

modules.title: Site security plan: defense in depth for the physical world

pages.title: Physical defense in depth: layers work together

content_blocks.text: Physical security is layered like technical security: outer perimeter → building access → internal zones → high-value areas.
Think in terms of **deterrence**, **delay**, **detection**, and **response**. You want attackers to be seen and slowed.
Site security plans vary by location because threats vary by geography and business activity.

checks.prompt: In physical security, “deterrence, delay, detection, response” describes:
checks.explanation: Those terms describe key goals of layered physical security controls.

pages.title: Security through obscurity: helpful, but not a substitute

content_blocks.text: In the physical world, being less noticeable can reduce casual targeting (e.g., unmarked call centers).
But hiding is not a complete control; you still need real security measures (access control, monitoring, policies).
Exam instinct: obscurity may reduce attention, but it does not replace proper controls.

checks.prompt: “Security through obscurity” is best described as:
options: A complete replacement for access control
Hiding resources to reduce attention, but not sufficient alone
checks.explanation: Obscurity can help but is not a reliable standalone control.

modules.title: Physical controls: fencing, bollards, lighting, and badges

pages.title: Fencing & bollards: perimeter control

content_blocks.text: **Fencing** defines boundaries and can slow or channel movement (often paired with cameras and lighting).
**Bollards** are posts/obstacles that prevent vehicle access—useful against accidents and vehicle-based attacks.
Exam cue: bollards = vehicle barrier; fences = perimeter boundary.

checks.prompt: Bollards are primarily used to:
options: Prevent vehicle access to an area
checks.explanation: Bollards are physical barriers designed to stop vehicles.

pages.title: Lighting and access badges: visibility + identity

content_blocks.text: Good **lighting** discourages intruders and supports cameras/guards by reducing dark areas.
**Access badges** can be magnetic stripe or RFID/proximity, often with photos/role info.
Badges are a target: attackers may steal, copy, or **clone RFID** to bypass controls—monitor for unusual access patterns.

checks.prompt: A key risk with RFID-based access badges is:
options: They can’t be used with proximity readers
RFID cloning can duplicate badge identifiers
checks.explanation: RFID cloning can copy tag/card identifiers, especially if RFID is the only identifier used.

modules.title: Physical access control + monitoring: mantraps, guards, cameras, sensors, attacks

pages.title: Mantraps + guards + visitor logs: stop piggybacking and enforce policy

content_blocks.text: **Access control vestibules** (mantraps) use two doors to limit entry and prevent piggybacking/tailgating.
**Security guards** add human decision-making: validate identity, escort visitors, monitor alarms/cameras.
Visitor logs support accountability—but remember: humans can be socially engineered, so training + procedures matter.

checks.prompt: An access control vestibule (mantrap) is primarily intended to prevent:
checks.explanation: Mantraps control entry so one person enters at a time, reducing piggybacking risk.

pages.title: Cameras, sensors, and physical attacks

content_blocks.text: **Video surveillance** can include motion detection buffers and object detection (watching specific areas/objects).
Sensors you must know: **infrared** (heat changes), **pressure** (movement/weight), **microwave** (field change), **ultrasonic** (sound).
Physical attacks to know: **brute force** (break/cut), **RFID cloning**, and **environmental** (HVAC/sprinklers). Pair detection (alarms/IDS) with response procedures.

checks.prompt: Which sensor type is commonly inexpensive and detects changes in heat/infrared radiation?
checks.explanation: Infrared sensors look for changes in heat/infrared radiation and are common in controlled indoor spaces.
